The **Baluchistan pygmy jerboa** (_**Salpingotulus michaelis**_) or **dwarf three-toed jerboa**, is a species of  in the family . It is the only species in the genus _**Salpingotulus**_. Adults average only 4.3 cm (1.7 in) in head and body length, with the tail averaging 8 cm (3.1 in). Adult females weigh 3.2 g (0.11 oz).] It is currently considered to be  to .] In the 1999 , it was listed as tied for the smallest rodent in the world with the .]
Distribution
------------
\\]
The species has been recorded from Pakistan and may occur in Afghanistan. It frequents sand dunes, gravel flats and plains in hot deserts.]
Ecology
-------
\\]
These nocturnal jerboas move through its dry desert habitat in long hops, balancing with the tail. They live in burrows generally excavated under small bushes. They feed on wind blown seeds, succulent leaves of desert-adapted vegetation, and various dead animals such as other rodents and lizards; food is raised to the mouth using the hands. As plants dry up, they are often left to dig up roots of desert plants and feast on them. They are omnivores. They undergo a  of physiological , when their bodily functions, including respiration and blood circulation, slow...[Content truncated]

[Content truncated]... authors to be in a separate genus, but its position on the phylogenetic tree constructed with use of morphological characteristics place it in the genus
                                 Salpingotus
                                , being sister group of Anguistodontus. Monotypic.
                            


                                 Distribution. SW Pakistan (Balochistan).
                                
View Figure



 Descriptive notes. Head-body 41-45 mm, tail 72-94 mm, ear 6-11 mm, hindfoot 18— 19 mm; weight 4 g. The Balochistan PygmyJerboa is very small. Condylo-basal lengths of skulls are 12:8-14-3 mm, mastoid breadths are 13-3-14-7 mm, and maxillary tooth row lengths are 2-6-2-8 mm. Head and dorsum are pale yellow-ocher or sandy buff; sides and ventral pelage are pure white. Tail is fatty, with relatively long black terminal tuft; fat deposits in tail are greatest in anterior one-third and rapidly become thinner toward tip. Hindfeet have three toes, covered below with brushes of white hairs; toes do not have conic calluses at bases. Ears are short and tubiform. Auditory bullae are greatly inflated and strongly project from under braincase laterally and caudally. Mastoid cavity is large and completely subdivided into three sections by septum. In volume, mastoid cavity is about twice as large as tympanic cavity. Front surfaces of incisors are yellow. P' is present and slightly smaller in diameter than M®. Molars are low-crowned, with tuberculous surfaces; crown heights of unworn molars are ¢.70% of their lengths. Glans penis is small, thin, elongated, cone-shaped, and not subdivided into lobes, with surface covered by very small single-vertex, backward-directed aciculae not differentiated in size. Os penis (baculum) is rudimentary and rachis-like; its length about equal to one-tenth of the length of glans penis.

 Habitat. Rolling sand dunes, sandy plains,orflat gravel plains with wind-moving sand layer in hot deserts at elevations of 1000-1600 m.

 Food and Feeding. The Balochistan Pygmy Jerboa mainly eats grass seeds and some other plant material.

 Breeding. Pregnant Balochistan Pygmy Jerboas were recorded in June-August...[Content truncated]

Query1.title: The Brain Scoop — Dipodidae Nobody quite got Friday's Freak of the...
Query1.snippet: Aug 20, 2012 ... ... Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, aka the dwarf three-toed jerboa – Salpingotulus michaelis – and is the only species in the genus Salpingotulus. In ...

content.content:
_**Dipodidae**_
Nobody quite got  – 
]
  and
]  came in the ballpark with their guesses of ‘kangaroo rat’, which is a relatively close assumption, however kangaroo rats are members of the family Heteromyidae.  Members of that family are more closely related to members of the pocket gopher family, Geomyidae. Most of the specimens photographed today are members of the family Dipodidae, which includes .
I’ve actually posted about that incredibly special individual before when I came across it  – it is the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, aka the dwarf three-toed jerboa – _Salpingotulus michaelis –_ and is the only species in the genus _Salpingotulus_.  In addition to the remarkable fact that this specimen is a rare sight in its native Pakistan habitat, back in 1967 it was confirmed that our museum was one of only five museums in the entire world to have one of these guys in their collection!
The other specimens photographed include the two largest jerboas identified as ’_Allactaga jaculus_’, which apparently is an outdated nomenclature combining two genera instead of a genus and a species name, so I can’t be positive what they actually are.  The third largest is Ord’s kangaroo rat (_Dipodomys ordii)_ of the family Heteromyidae, included to show the similarities between members of the same family.  To contrast, the second-to-smallest is the western jumping mouse (_Zapus princeps)_ which is in the family Dipodidae, but looks less similar than the Ord’s kangaroo rat.  WHEW – did you get all of that?!
Secondly, a gigantic THANK YOU to everyone who left comments and sent messages for suggestions on improving this blog!  I’m so pleased to see so many of you invested and interested in this project, and really value your input, so a tremendous thanks again.
Did I mention that you can now  texts/video/photos/ for identification?! I don’t know why I didn’t enable this feature sooner!  Stay tuned for another post later today where I will talk about some identification techniques, and mention a few good books for ID reference.  It’s going to be AWESOME

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Brain Scoop is related to educational content about animal biology and conservation. Being a Tumblr blog, however, often leads to user-generated content that may lack rigorous fact-checking. While it provides interesting insights and can be informative, its credibility is not guaranteed compared to scholarly sources. Thus, it would be prudent to corroborate facts with reliable academic sources.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This reference discusses the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, indicating it is the only species in its genus. While it provides some comparative context and mentions its rarity, it lacks specific details about identifying features that substantiate the claim regarding the photo.

The **Baluchistan pygmy jerboa** (_Salpingotulus michaelis_) is a very small  in the family Dipodidae. In the 1999 Guinness Book of Records, it was listed as tied for the smallest rodent in the world with the .
Appearance
----------
Adult Baluchistan pygmy jerboas average only 4.3 cm (1.7 in) in head and body length, with the tail averaging 8 cm (3.1 in). Adult females weigh 3.2 g (0.11 oz). They have long hind legs, short forelegs, and long tails. The fur is fine, the color of sand and matches the habitat these rodents live in.
Distribution
------------
### Geography
Continents
Subcontinents
Countries
WWF Biomes
Baluchistan pygmy jerboas are found in Pakistan and may occur in Afghanistan. They live in sand dunes, gravel flats, and plains in hot deserts.
### Biome
### Climate zones
Habits and Lifestyle
--------------------
Baluchistan pygmy jerboas are nocturnal. They move around in long hops, balancing with the tail. They live in burrows which they usually excavate under small bushes. Baluchistan pygmy jerboas undergo a diurnal rhythm of physiological dormancy, when their bodily functions, including respiration and blood circulation, slow down dramatically. This is known as facultative hypothermia and helps jerbo...[Content truncated]

Query2.title: Top 10: Earth's smallest mammals - BBC Science Focus Magazine
Query2.snippet: 1. Batodonoides vanhouteni (extinct) · 2. Etruscan shrew · 3. Kitti's hog-nosed bat · 4. African pygmy mouse · 5. Baluchistan pygmy jerboa · 6. Long-tailed planigale.

content.content:
[Content truncated]...osed planigale © dnatheist, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons - © dnatheist - https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0
**Weight:** 5.3g
**Distribution:** Australia
_Planigaletenuirostris_, though it measures only up to 7.5cm, is a vicious predator. It takes down insects and small lizards, occasionally even ones bigger than itself.
6\. Long-tailed planigale
-------------------------
!
**Weight:** 4.3g
**Distribution:** Australia
_Planigale ingrami_is the last planigale on this list, and is the world's smallest marsupial. Its head and body are only 55-65mm long.
Females of the species weigh on average 4.3g, whereas males weigh an average of 4.2g.
5\. Baluchistan pygmy jerboa
----------------------------
!
**Weight:** 3.75g
**Distribution:** Pakistan and Afghanistan
According to the , the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa is joint with the African pygmy mouse for the title of the world's smallest rodent.
__Salpingotulus michaelis__, or the dwarf three-toed jerboa, has a body around 4.4cm long, and a tail of 8cm. On average, adult females weigh 3.75g.
4\. African pygmy mouse
-----------------------
!
African pygmy mouse © Alouise Lynch, CC BY-SA 4.0 , via Wikimedia Commons - © Alouise Lynch via Wikimedia Commons - https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0
**Weight:** 3-12g; average 7.2g
**Distribution:** Sub-Saharan Africa
The African pygmy mouse,_Mus minutoides_, holds the joint title for the world's smallest rodent with the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa.
Its body is 6-8cm long, with an additional 3-6cm in length coming from its tail.
3\. Kitti's hog-nosed bat
-------------------------
!
Kitti's hog-nosed bat © Sébastien J. Puechmaille1,\*, Pipat Soisook2, Medhi Yokubol2, Piyathip Piyapan2,Meriadeg Ar Gouilh3, 4, Khin Mie Mie...[Content truncated]

The Baluchistan Pygmy Jerboa Is Half-Mouse, Half-Kangaroo and All Awesome
=========================================================================
Kelly Dickerson
Updated February 24, 2016 at 4:23 PM
Link Copied
A tiny creature that looks like a cross between a cotton ball and a miniature kangaroo might be the cutest rodent we've ever seen.
!
Source: 
It's called a Baluchistan Pygmy Jerboa. The tiny creatures are about 2 inches long, earning them the title of . According to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature's , they're native to the deserts of Pakistan.
Their comically large feet allow them to  around like kangaroos, and they have highly sensitive hearing so they can detect predators approaching, according to .
!

Most of the specimens photographed today are members of the family Dipodidae, which includes .
I’ve actually posted about that incredibly special individual before when I came across it  – it is the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, aka the dwarf three-toed jerboa – _Salpingotulus michaelis –_ and is the only species in the genus _Salpingotulus_.  In addition to the remarkable fact that this specimen is a rare sight in its native Pakistan habitat, back in 1967 it was confirmed that our museum was one of only five museums in the entire world to have one of these guys in their collection!
The other specimens photographed include the two largest jerboas identified as ’_Allactaga jaculus_’, which apparently is an outdated nomenclature combining two genera instead of a genus and a species name, so I can’t be positive what they actually are.  The third largest is Ord’s kangaroo rat (_Dipodomys ordii)_ of the family Heteromyidae, included to show the similarities between members of the same family.  To contrast, the second-to-smallest is the western jumping mouse (_Zapus princeps)_ which is in the family Dipodidae, but looks less similar than the Ord’s kangaroo rat.  WHEW – did you get all of that?!
Secondly, a gigantic THANK YOU to everyone who left comments and sent messages for suggestions on improving this blog!  I’m so pleased to see so many of you invested and interested in this project, and really value your input, so a tremendous thanks again.

QA.Question: What evidence supports the claim that the rodent in the photo is indeed a Baluchistan pygmy jerboa?
QA.Answer:
The claim that the rodent in the photo is a Baluchistan pygmy jerboa (Salpingotulus michaelis) can be supported by several pieces of evidence:

1. **Taxonomy and Identification**: The Baluchistan pygmy jerboa is known as the smallest rodent in the world, with adults averaging about 4.3 cm in body length and a tail length of around 8 cm. It falls within the family Dipodidae, which is the family to which jerboas belong. This specific classification supports the identification of the rodent if it aligns with these measurements and characteristics [Query1_evidence1].

2. **Physical Characteristics**: The rodent is characterized by its pale yellow-ocher or sandy buff coloration, with a white underbelly. This distinctive fur coloration matches descriptions of the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa, which helps in confirming its identity when visual characteristics are considered [Query1_evidence2].

3. **Habitat and Behavior**: The Baluchistan pygmy jerboa is native to sandy habitats in its range, which includes places like Balochistan in Pakistan. The rodent’s described behaviors in the video, particularly its inquisitive and exploratory nature, may align with the typical lifestyle of the pygmy jerboa, which is known to forage and hop around in its environment [Query1_evidence1].

4. **Comparative Size and Features**: The evidence indicates that the Baluchistan pygmy jerboa is much smaller than typical rodents like mice or hamsters. If the rodent in the photo truly exhibits the small stature typical of this species, it strengthens the case for its identity as a Baluchistan pygmy jerboa [Query1_evidence2].

Overall, the evidence supports the claim with a reasonable degree of confidence that the rodent in the photo is indeed a Baluchistan pygmy jerboa.
